The proposed pipeline can help mitigate human and property losses caused by tropical cyclones (TCs). Despite extensive research on TCs from various angles, more work is needed to improve prediction accuracy. The current state-of-the-art in TC prediction bands comes from the National Hurricane Center at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), which provides "cones of uncertainty" for TCs through historical forecast error analysis (NOAA/NHC, 2018). This paper contributes to the field in two ways. First, we introduce a new pipeline that streamlines TC track simulation and prediction band generation, making it more transparent and adaptable. Second, we provide updates to existing models and novel statistical methodologies in both areas of the pipeline.

Our pipeline has several desirable properties. It provides an easy-to-use framework for estimating prediction bands for new TCs. The pipeline consists of two separable components: TC track simulation and prediction band creation. Each component is designed to be interchangeable, allowing users to replace them with their preferred methods, provided the input and output are the same. We provide data-driven TC simulation approaches, but users can easily pair these with other meteorological methods, which is crucial in a climate change scenario where TC behavior may change drastically in a short period.

Our current pipeline is implemented as an R package and is available on GitHub. Section 2 details the pipeline's structure and components. We extend current statistical methods for TC simulations by combining autoregressive path prediction models (Vickery et al., 2000) and models of TC lifespan (Hall & Jewson, 2007). We propose novel statistically valid prediction bands by leveraging geometric properties and statistical notions on the depth and centrality of simulated curves. We benchmark our methods against the prediction bands creation technique found in NOAA's state-of-the-art model (NOAA/NHC, 2018).

We construct prediction band methods that provide coverage in either a pointwise or uniform manner, aiming to cover future measurements of the TC path or the full TC track, respectively. Section 3 discusses these contributions in detail, presents experimental results on held-out data, and provides empirical assessments of the prediction band methods' statistical properties.

Figure 1 provides a schematic representation of our proposed pipeline. The leftmost stage corresponds to the input, which is a series of spatiotemporal measurements of a TC track. We rely on publicly available data from the Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory of NOAA (Land-sea & Franklin, 2013; NOAA/AOML, 2017). Each path has information on time, latitude, and longitude, recorded every six hours until the storm dissipates. For each new TC, the pipeline uses a few initial points to simulate a series of tracks the TC could traverse. The curve simulation models are tuned according to computational complexity and available processing power.

When training the track simulation model, the training TC paths should be representative of the world region for which the pipeline will make predictions. Once these simulations are generated, the next stage uses this ensemble to produce a prediction band at a chosen statistical confidence level, usually between 90% and 99%. The confidence refers to the statistical coverage of the prediction band, i.e., the rate at which the prediction band covers the true TC points or the full TC track.

The pipeline is model-agnostic, meaning the choices of statistical framework or machine learning models do not affect the structure or flow of the pipeline, provided the input and output of each stage are not changed. Similarly, a more granular or richer input will not affect the pipeline's performance.
